 I. 

THE ONGOING PROJECT 

 
1. 
On  December  2013,  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  approved  a  multitranche 
financing  facility  (MFF)  for  the  Ulaanbaatar  Urban  Services  and  Ger  Areas  Development 
Investment Program, comprising three tranches and with implementation period of 9 years, from 
December 2013 to December 2022.1 The MFF program's impact is improved living conditions in 
Ulaanbaatar; and its intended outcome is a network of livable, competitive, and inclusive subcenters 
in  Ulaanbaatar's  ger  areas,  which  is  being  achieved  through  four  outputs:  (i) roads  and  urban 
services  are  expanded  within  priority  subcenters  and  connectivity  between  them  is  improved; 
(ii) economic  and  public  services  in  targeted  areas  are  improved;  (iii)  service  providers  become 
more efficient; and (iv) institutions and capacity for urban development, program management, and 
service delivery are strengthened. The program's framework financing agreement was signed on 
9 December 2013 and ratified by the Mongolian Parliament on 23 May 2014. 
 
2. 

The summary financing plan of the program is in Table 1.

3. 
Tranche 1 of the MFF program was approved on 17 December 2013 and became effective 
on  24  September  2014,  with  revised  completion  date  of  31 December  2019.  Tranche  1 
implementation is progressing satisfactorily. Its cumulative contract awards as of 25 April 2019 is 
$41.32  million  (76.95%)  with  cumulative  disbursements  of  $18.38  million  (34.23%).  Tranche  2 
was  approved  on  31  March  2017  and  became  effective  on  14  March  2018,  with  expected 
completion date of 28 February 2022. A plant contract and two consulting services contracts have 
been awarded under Tranche 2 amounting to $12.67 million (19.09%). No disbursements have 
been  made to  date  pending  the  program management  office's (PMO)  opening  of  the  advance 
account for  this tranche.  Processing  of Tranche 3  has  started  and  the  approval  is  targeted for 
2020. 
 
4. 
were approved by ADB: 

To  support  the  implementation  of  the  MFF  program,  two  technical  assistance  projects 

(i) 

Ulaanbaatar Pro-Poor Urban Redevelopment Support System for Ger Areas.2 
This transaction technical assistance (TRTA), for $500,000, is piloting information 

                                                 
1  ADB.  2013.  Report  and  Recommendation  of  the  President  to  the  Board  of  Directors:  Proposed  Multitranche 
Financing Facility to Mongolia for the Ulaanbaatar Urban Services and Ger Areas Development Investment Program. 
Manila. 

2  ADB. 2018. Technical Assistance to Mongolia for Ulaanbaatar Pro-Poor Urban Redevelopment Support System for 

Ger Areas. Manila. 

 

 

 and  communication  technology  (ICT)  tools  for  ger  area  redevelopment  in 
enhancing municipality-level urban and redevelopment planning with mapping and 
monitoring indicators, supporting inclusive community engagement and access to 
economic opportunities in ger areas, and strengthening redevelopment monitoring 
and coordination capacity; and 
Livelihood  Support  Demonstration  in  Ger  Areas.  This  small-scale  technical 
assistance (SSTA), for $125,000, is being implemented to support the poor and 
vulnerable households adversely affected by involuntary resettlement in the design 
and  implementation  of  pilot  livelihood  demonstration  programs  by  enhancing 
employable skills, training and business development, creating home-based jobs, 
and  increasing  opportunities  for  job  placements,  under  Tranche  1  of  the  MFF 
program.3 

(ii) 

 

II. 

THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 

Justification 

 
A. 
 
5. 
About  840,000  of  the  1.4  million  population  of  Ulaanbaatar  City  live  in  ger  (traditional 
moveable dwelling) areas. The urban poor and most vulnerable people live in ger areas. From 
2014 to 2016, the poverty rate in Mongolia's urban areas increased from 18.8% to 29.6 %. The 
urban poor in the ger area communities have limited access to basic services and face economic 
hardships due to lack of investments that prevents any improvement of their standards of living. 
Ger  areas  have  high  levels  of  air,  water,  and  soil  pollution  and  are  also  vulnerable  to  climate 
change  and  natural  disasters.    As  ger  areas  continue  to  grow  and  densify  due  to  urban 
development  and  immigration,  inadequacy  of  basic  infrastructure  services,  public  space,  and 
commercial services has become more serious. Modernization of ger areas is the main urban, 
social, and environmental challenge of Mongolia.  
 
Many initiatives, pilots, and projects have been implemented to redevelop and modernize 
6. 
ger areas through construction of basic infrastructure, communal facilities, and affordable housing. 
The involuntary resettlement impacts triggered by these ger area redevelopment initiatives would 
increase poverty and vulnerability of affected households, if such initiatives are not accompanied 
by livelihood support opportunities. Most of the future investments in ger areas are expected from 
the government and the private sector. Both the government and the private sector are still not 
well  aware  of  best  practices  in  resettlement. Therefore,  it  is  necessary  to  urgently  ensure that 
resettlement  processes  associated  with  redevelopment  of  ger  areas  follow  resettlement  best 
practices for the benefit of the affected people.  
 
7. 
The  proposed  TRTA  will  provide  capacity  development  support  to  the  Municipality  of 
Ulaanbaatar  (MUB)  to  institutionalize  an  approach  to  plan,  design,  and  implement  livelihood 
support programs that target affected households whose livelihoods were adversely affected by 
involuntary resettlement.4 It is expected to (i) strengthen project implementation procedures and 
approaches  in  managing  involuntary  resettlement  and  livelihood  impacts  of  development 
interventions in ger areas, and (ii) build the capacity of MUB in the management of involuntary 
resettlement and livelihood restoration programs. It will also scale-up the pilot activities conducted 

                                                 
3  A livelihood support plan for each of the two subcenters (Bayankhoshuu and Selbe) is being implemented under the 
SSTA  and  includes  the  following  livelihood  support  measures  to  the  poor  and  vulnerable  affected  households: 
(i) vocational  skills  and  capacity  development  training;  (ii)  home-based  business  development  support,  through 
business facilitation and equipment supply; and (iii) support in creating long-term employment opportunities. 

4   For purposes of the proposed TRTA, affected households refer to households whose livelihoods have been adversely 

affected by involuntary resettlement activities under the MFF program. 

2 

 

 Outputs and Activities 

under the SSTA (para. 4) by including affected households whose livelihoods are impacted under 
the MFF program and will build on experiences and lessons from the implementation of the SSTA 
and the involuntary resettlement process under Tranche 1, including recent resettlement activities 
of other donors and organizations. 
 
8. 
Although the TRTA is not included in the approved country operations business plan for 
Mongolia,  2019–2021,  it  is  in  accordance  with  the  (i)  ADB's  country  partnership  strategy  for 
Mongolia, 2017–20205 on supporting urban operations; (ii) Government Action Plan, 2016–2020, 
which  proposes  to  upgrade  existing  norms  and  standards  in  conformity  with  international 
standards and create an environment suitable to apply international norms and standardization 
documents;  and  (iii)  ongoing  engagement  with  CSOs  and  community  representatives  in 
Mongolia.6   
 
B. 
 
9. 
Output  1:  Livelihood  restoration  and  support  programs  for  affected  households 
implemented.  The  TRTA  will  design  and  implement  livelihood  improvement  and  support 
programs  together  with  MUB.  The  TRTA  team  at  inception  stage  will  (i)  analyze  the 
socioeconomic  survey  findings  in  the  ger  areas;  (ii)  conduct  a  needs  assessment  of  affected 
households;7 (iii)  review  the  implementation  of  the  SSTA  activities  to  identify  successful  pilot 
livelihood  support  programs;  (iv)  review  ICT  tools  and  systems  that  have  been  developed  to 
enhance  business  and  investment  support  services  in  the  ger  areas;  and  (v)  carry  out 
consultations with businesses in ger areas and organizations working on research and capacity 
building  related  to  livelihoods  and  productivity  of  micro-small  medium  enterprises  in  Mongolia, 
including  the  Asian  Productivity  Organization,    to  identify  any  existing  barriers  that  limit  the 
productivity and growth of ger-based and ger-managed enterprises. The needs assessment of 
affected households will include collection of gender disaggregated information and help identify 
differentiated livelihood impacts of the project on men and women. These inputs will be used for 
development  and  prioritization  of  potential  livelihood  support  activities  in  consultation  with  the 
affected  persons  and  other  stakeholders.  The  livelihood  support  will  enhance  employability 
through skills development, provide training on business development, improve financial literacy, 
provide tools and equipment for the affected households,8 and widen access to credit sources, 
and increase opportunities for job placements.  
 
10. 
The  design  and  implementation  of  livelihood  interventions  will  be  (i)  responsive  to  the 
specific needs of each household and attuned to its level of preparedness; (ii) geared towards 
self-determination  and  empowerment  rather  than  dependence;  and  (iii)  gender-sensitive  and 
environmentally sound. The TRTA will explore avenues to engage CSOs and community groups 
in planning, designing, implementing, and monitoring involuntary resettlement programs to build 
their  capacity,  ownership,  and  empowerment;  and  facilitate  their  involvement  to  benefit  from 
infrastructure projects. 
 
11. 
In addition, the TRTA will (i) identify opportunities to incorporate livelihood support function 
within  the  business  incubator  facility  built  under  the  MFF  program,  Deutsche  Gesellschaft  für 
Internationale Zusammenarbeit's (GIZ) "Build for Skills Program" initiative under Tranche 1, and 

                                                 
5   ADB. 2017. Country Partnership Strategy: Mongolia, 2017–2020. Manila. 
6  The TRTA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB's website on 26 April 2019. 
7   The needs assessment and survey of affected households shall be designed to capture livelihood impacts on women 

members of the affected households.  

8   Equipment  that  contribute  to  improved  incomes  and  livelihoods  of  the  affected  households,  such  as  sewing 

machines, automobile repair tools, and welding equipment. 

3 

 

 other donors' and government's initiatives; and (ii) review and assess the benefits of livelihood 
improvement  under  Tranche  1,  the  contribution  to  economic  and  social  development  of 
Ulaanbaatar  City,  and  how  the  private  sector  can  integrate  livelihood  restoration  and  support 
program in their activities. To continuously assess the impacts of the livelihood support activities 
under this TRTA, a concurrent monitoring and evaluation of the TRTA activities will be carried out 
to (i) identify any red flags and corrective actions in the implementation of the TRTA objectives, 
and (ii) help contribute to the sustainability of the TRTA activities in future ger area redevelopment 
projects in Mongolia.  
 
12. 
Output 2: A sustainable model on integrating livelihood support to persons affected 
by urban resettlement planning in Mongolia established. The experiences gained from the 
implementation of Output 1 of the TRTA and the two technical assistance projects (para. 4) will 
provide inputs to the development of a sustainable model that will integrate livelihood support to 
persons affected by redevelopment and urban resettlement in the ger areas. The model will be 
aligned  with  any  existing  policy  or  strategies  of  the  Government  of  Mongolia  on  enterprise 
development  and  productivity  improvement.  The  model  will  guide  MUB,  relevant  government 
agencies,  CSOs,  private  sector,  and  other  donors  engaged  in  infrastructure  development  in 
Ulaanbaatar to  integrate  and  address  livelihood  restoration. It  will  also  provide  suggestions  on 
how to improve urban resettlement planning and implementation. The TRTA is expected to have 
demonstrable benefits that can be replicated and developed into sustainable livelihood restoration 
programs. A knowledge product in the form of a policy paper will be produced, incorporating the 
results from consultations with stakeholder groups and affected communities.  
 
13. 
Output 3: The capacity of the Municipality of Ulaanbaatar to develop and implement 
livelihood support programs strengthened. Capacity building under the proposed TRTA will 
aim  at  (i)  developing  skills  and  knowledge  of  the  Land  Agency  and  PMO  staff  under  MUB  on 
policy  advice  and  knowledge  management  dissemination  of  best  practices  in  involuntary 
resettlement and livelihood restoration; and (ii) institutionalizing resettlement and social safeguard 
best  practices  at  MUB,  to  benefit  future  urban  development  and  infrastructure  programs  in 
Mongolia.  Capacity  building  initiatives  will  focus  on  concepts  of  and  approaches  to  livelihood 
improvement  of  affected  persons  and  implementation  of  programs  through  external  service 
providers, including training institutes, individual experts, private companies, and NGOs. Training 
manuals  will  be  produced  and  translated  into  local  languages,  and  training  e-modules  will  be 
developed for MUB staff to carry out training on livelihood improvement. The training modules will 
include  gender-specific  approaches 
improvement  and  skills 
enhancement needs of women. About 25 MUB staff from the Land Agency and PMO, of which at 
least  30%  will  be  women,  will  be  trained  on  implementation  of  ADB  involuntary  resettlement 
safeguards apart from planning and implementation of livelihood restoration programs.  
 
14. 
Design and monitoring framework. The capacity development support to be provided 
by the proposed TRTA will not result to a change in the design and monitoring framework of the 
ongoing MFF program and its tranches. The TRTA will enhance the quality of outputs without any 
change to the targeted results indicators. 
 
C. 
 
15. 
The TRTA is estimated to cost $720,000, of which $660,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB's Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6). The key expenditure items are listed 
in Appendix 1. The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, 
office accommodation, office supplies, secretarial assistance including translators, and other in-
kind contributions.

Implementation Arrangements 

D. 
 
16. 
ADB  will  administer  the  TRTA;  and  will  select,  evaluate,  appoint,  and  supervise 
consultants. The executing agency will be MUB supported by the PMO administering the MFF 
program. The implementation arrangements are summarized in Table 2.

17. 
Consulting services. One international and five national experts will be engaged using 
individual consultants selection method, for a total of 56 person-months inputs, to support TRTA 
implementation activities.9 The consultants will procure goods (on behalf of ADB) required for the 
provision  of  livelihood  support  to  affected  households.  Engagement  of  consultants  and 
procurement of goods will be in accordance with the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended 
from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions and/or staff instructions.  
 

III. 

THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 

 
18. 
The  President,  acting  under  the  authority  delegated  by  the  Board,  has  approved  the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $660,000 on a grant basis to the 
Government of Mongolia for Capacity Building for Sustainable Livelihood Support in Ger Areas, 
and hereby reports this action to the Board. 

                                                 
9  Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). Output-based terms 

of reference and lumpsum contract will be considered.
